prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We trigger the TOO observation of this target (= science goal) when the hardness ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4--10 keV and 2--4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.4 in the decaying phase (after the peak of X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform the observation (as soon as possible) within 4 weeks after the TOO trigger (i.e., the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux in a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for each target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle-2 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 targets = 6 hours at the maximum.)

We trigger the TOO observation of this target (= science goal) when the hardness ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4--10 keV and 2--4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.7 in the decaying phase (after the peak of X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform the observation (as soon as possible) within 4 weeks after the TOO trigger (i.e., the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux in a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for each target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle-2 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 targets = 6 hours at the maximum.)

We trigger the TOO observation of this target (= science goal) when the hardness ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4--10 keV and 2--4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.6 in the decaying phase (after the peak of X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform the observation (as soon as possible) within 4 weeks after the TOO trigger (i.e., the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux in a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for each target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle-2 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 targets = 6 hours at the maximum.)

We trigger the TOO observation of this target (= science goal) when the hardness ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4--10 keV and 2--4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.7 in the decaying phase (after the peak of X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform the observation (as soon as possible) within 4 weeks after the TOO trigger (i.e., the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux in a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for each target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle-2 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 targets = 6 hours at the maximum.)

We trigger the TOO observation of this target (= science goal) when the hardness ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4--10 keV and 2--4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.4 in the decaying phase (after the peak of X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform the observation (as soon as possible) within 4 weeks after the TOO trigger (i.e., the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux in a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for each target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle-2 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 targets = 6 hours at the maximum.)

We trigger the TOO observation of this target (= science goal) when the hardness ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4--10 keV and 2--4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 1.4 in the decaying phase (after the peak of X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform the observation (as soon as possible) within 4 weeks after the TOO trigger (i.e., the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux in a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for each target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle-2 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 targets = 6 hours at the maximum.)

We trigger the TOO observation of this target (= science goal) when the hardness ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4--10 keV and 2--4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.7. Cyg X-1 is persistently bright in X-rays unlike other targets. It stays in the low/hard state almost all the time but sometimes exhibits a state transition to the high/soft state. We therefore trigger the TOO observation of Cyg X-1 when the condition described above is satisfied, without considering whether the X-ray flux is increasing or decreasing. We request to perform the observation (as soon as possible) within 4 weeks after the TOO trigger (i.e., the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux in a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for each target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle-2 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 targets = 6 hours at the maximum.)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the biggest questions left in high energy astrophysics is the mechanism to form the relativistic jets from accreting black holes. Here we propose to carry out first TOO polarimetry of transient Galactic black hole X-ray binaries in the mm band, to study the magnetic field structures of compact, steady jets ubiquitously seen in low mass accretion rates. To trigger the observations, we monitor the X-ray lightcurves and spectra of our targets using the all-sky X-ray monitor MAXI. The ALMA's high sensitivity enables us for the first time to detect the polarized synchrotron component in the mm band and to constrain the magnetic field configuration in the base of the jets. We are also preparing for simultaneous multi-wavelength observations including X-ray, near infrared and optical bands. They are expected to provide great synergy with the ALMA observations, by allowing us to investigate the structure of the inner accretion disk and to estimate the magnetic field strength and energy distribution of electrons in the jet base.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, Kyoto University
